Rupert Pupkin.Action: Delivers packages while always courteous and polite.
Walks rapidly toward the television theater with focus, but appears distracted when responding to others.
Dresses neatly and professionally; courteous and polite in his behavior during his messenger rounds, showing self-presentation and social awareness.
Appears distracted and unable to get autographs or meaningful recognition from the crowd despite being present at a key location.
Attempts to remain apart from other professionals, expresses disinterest in their bidding/interaction.
Shoots a hostile glance back at Celeste.
Carefully positions himself near the door, away from others, attempts to remain aloof from the group's negotiations.
Turns and directly states to Sidney that he is not interested and that the matter is not his whole life.
Responds with a hostile glance to Celeste's comment.
Engages the young girl in conversation about Jerry's autograph in a friendly manner.
Shows no dismissiveness or rudeness to the young couple nearby.
Smiles pleasantly at Langford amid a tense situation and questions the lack of security with concern.
Yells at the crowd and pushes people aside to clear a path for Langford, urging the crowd to have heart.
Smiles pleasantly at Langford and calmly comments on the poor security, noticing details others miss.
Speaks loudly and authoritatively to the crowd, attempts to control the situation by pushing people aside and ordering them to stand back.
Fails to get a response or cooperation from Langford, who barely listens and looks nervous.
Opens limo door for LANGFORD, holds door with a pleasant smile.
Politely asks for a moment of LANGFORD's time, acknowledges his busyness and promises not to take long.
Shows vulnerability by asking if LANGFORD has a handkerchief for his scratched hand, expresses frustration about the crowd.
Offers to talk as LANGFORD drives and be dropped off anywhere, showing flexibility and consideration.
Pressures LANGFORD by saying 'I put myself on the line for you,' creating obligation.
Takes initiative to open limo door and invites Langford in first, showing confidence and social skill.
Politely persuades Langford to give him time despite Langford's reluctance, demonstrating persistence and social savvy.
Acknowledges Langford's busy schedule and offers to adapt to his time constraints, showing tact and awareness.
Mentions his injured hand and asks Langford for a handkerchief, showing vulnerability but also practical awareness.
Offers a cigarette as a courtesy despite not smoking himself, also offers a cough drop to Langford.
Reveals intense admiration for Jerry and shares personal ambitions openly.
Self-praises as 'really good' and 'dynamite', focusing on own talent and success.
Compliments Jerry's style warmly, calling him a teacher and a friend.
Asks Jerry sincerely for a break and help, expressing vulnerability about his age and career status.
Insists on being heard despite clear hesitation and resistance from Jerry.
Persists in pursuing Jerry despite being an outsider, invites himself into the car showing initiative and determination.
Displays self-awareness about the difficulty of breaking into the business, framing it as needing to make your own breaks.
Attempts to repay Jerry by offering dinner despite being short on cash, showing social tact and polite persistence.
Extends the wrong hand for a handshake (left instead of right), creating an awkward moment.
Tries to bond with Jerry by offering a joke even as Jerry is trying to leave, showing persistence but potentially overstepping boundaries.
Invites Langford to lunch, offers to pay (My treat).
Thanks Langford for the handkerchief, showing appreciation.
Pushes a five dollar bill to restaurant owner to secure a good table.
Presents a rehearsed opening line to Langford, showing preparation and effort.
Waves after Langford and insists on lunch, showing social initiative and confidence.
Unwraps Langford's handkerchief without explicit permission, which may show awkwardness or lack of social awareness.
Successfully charms the restaurant owner and gets seated in a good spot by tipping, demonstrating social skill and resourcefulness.

Makes light, witty remarks with the waiter, engages in friendly banter, and offers sympathy and support to Jerry Langford, suggesting thoughtful insight about the problems with the show and audience fatigue.
Attempts to analyze show problems and suggests an insightful diagnosis (too many of the same faces causing audience loss), indicating strategic thinking and confidence in his assessment.
Writes a flattering autograph to the young girl, showing confidence and self-promotion.
Proposes himself as the unknown brilliant talent for the show, showing ambition and a strategic idea to create suspense.
Offers to appear on the show at Guild scale and support Langford, showing confidence and willingness to work his way up.
Takes Langford's handkerchief and folds it reverentially, tucking it carefully into his breast pocket.
Claps his hands together for joy and hails a cab after the toast.
Buys a single red rose and goes to see Rita, an old acquaintance, showing interest in her life and greeting her warmly.
Smiles knowingly and engages politely with Rita, making friendly conversation about mutual acquaintances and their lives.
Dashes quickly to a florist, purchases a rose, and finds Rita at the bar showing memory and social awareness to connect with her.
Tries to maintain a confident and knowing smile when confronting Rita despite her initial disbelief.
Brings Rita a rose and some Rolaids, tries to engage her warmly and compliments her sincerely.
Admits nervousness about telling Rita she was 'Most Beautiful' and waits for the right timing to approach.
Rattles on without noticing Rita's growing discomfort and awkwardness.
Tries to engage Rita in conversation with humor and smiles, attempts to change her negative perception of him.
Insists on being called by his name rather than a term of endearment, showing discomfort with casual affection.
Attempts casual conversation and jokingly distinguishes himself from a famous person to build rapport.
Fails to read social cues as Rita is disbelieving and amused rather than engaged; he awkwardly waits for a laugh that doesn't come.
Asks Rita out after many years of buildup, showing some measure of courage and planning.
Unable to handle Rita's derisive laughter and dismissiveness gracefully, responding with a defensive and awkward insistence on his identity.
Invites Rita to celebrate and get to know each other, expresses desire for connection.
Ignores Rita's clear disinterest and prior commitments, presses for a date.
Shows uneasiness and vulnerability while watching others interact, seeking social connection.
Questions Rita about her date intrusively, ignoring social boundaries.
Attempts to initiate a connection and plans multiple meetings, demonstrating persistence and a clear goal.
Fails to understand or respond appropriately to direct questions about a job offer, seeming evasive and unclear.
Insists on a date despite Rita's multiple refusals and preexisting commitments, showing poor social awareness and lack of adaptability.
Is observant enough to notice Rita going off to chat with another man but only awkwardly calls her back, showing limited social tact.
Pressures Rita to cancel her plans and spend time with him despite her reluctance.
Tries to share his excitement about future plans with Rita, wanting to include her.
Sneaks furtive glances at another man's genitalia in the restroom, displaying discomfort and awkwardness.
Insists that Rita tell another man she's busy to go out with him, showing persistence in pursuit of his goal.
Expresses that tonight is 'everything' without explaining why, showing emotional intensity but lack of clear communication.
When Rita leaves him and returns to the other man, Pupkin does not assertively follow up or change strategy, showing passivity.
In the john, awkwardly engages in tense non-verbal interaction and furtive glances with the other man, indicating social discomfort and insecurity.
After emerging, calls Rita over to talk and attempts to convince her about a big upcoming opportunity, showing some confidence and forward planning.
Fails to provide convincing or concrete details about the 'something really big,' limiting persuasive effectiveness.
Shrugs an apology after causing a mess at the bar.
Glances distastefully at a man's hand on his shoulder, showing discomfort with forced friendliness.

Slides beer bottle down the bar which accidentally causes a mess by knocking over another glass, earning glare from others.
Shrugs an apology and does not escalate the conflict after causing the mess.
Shows distaste and discomfort when a man puts his hand on his shoulder, but controls himself and remains seated with no aggressive reaction.
Burps in response to a tense moment, then raises his glass again, indicating some confidence or defiance.
Silently endures the MAN pouring beer into his breast pocket without protest.
Passively sits while RITA and the MAN expect him to join in, but he remains silent and withdrawn.
After being treated cruelly (prodded with foot), he retaliates by striking the MAN over the head with a chair.
Brushes off his suit and stands over the unconscious MAN in a posture mirroring the MAN's previous dominance.
Passively allows the MAN to pour beer into his breast pocket and does not respond to social cues to interact (no call for beer).
Feigns unconsciousness by falling from barstool and lying inert on the floor.
Carefully opens one eye, grabs a chair, and smartly knocks the MAN out to defend himself.
Brushes off his suit and adopts a confident stance over the knocked-out MAN, mirroring the MAN’s previous posture.
Turns around smiling when Rita tries to touch a man's arm, causing her to be startled but amused.
Engages in light, playful conversation with Rita about thinking of her and responds shyly.
Attempts to engage Rita in conversation and serves her food despite awkwardness.
Drops his eyes when Rita criticizes the tablecloths, showing discomfort or insecurity.

Shows devotion by recalling seeing Rita perform every year.
Acknowledges Rita's nose wiggling when she talks, showing some attentiveness and openness to new information.

Drops his eyes when Rita questions the quality of the tablecloths, suggesting a lack of confidence or discomfort.
Insists that the evening is very important to him, showing seriousness and focus.
Compliments the show genuinely ('I liked the show.')

Engages Rita in personal conversation, shows curiosity about her life and favorites.

Attempts to share his excitement and dreams with Rita, trying to include her in his vision of success.
Insists strongly on his own importance despite Rita's dismissive attitude, showing some insensitivity to her feelings.
Confidently talks about his upcoming big break and national TV appearance, showing determination and clear ambition.
Insists on his own stardom despite others laughing at him, indicating possible overconfidence or lack of self-awareness.

Keeps Rita's presence a secret from others to protect her privacy.
Ignores Rita's financial struggles and practical needs (her request for money).
Convinces Rita with a grand vision of success and a better life, showing confidence and persuasion skills.

Accusing Rita of not caring and stares at her icily after she mentions leaving.

Accusing Rita and showing icy stare, appearing emotionally unsettled and failing to read the social cues effectively.

Self-pitying and somewhat awkward speech implying he is vulnerable and unsure about how the listener (Jerry) perceives him.

Admits he is no good at knots but improvises by asking Jerry to cooperate, demonstrating practical problem-solving.
Uses 'demonic force' to pin Jerry down when Jerry tries to grab him, displaying assertiveness and physical capability.
Shakes his head sadly and sounds discouraged after Langford's assurances, indicating possible internal conflict or doubt.
Gently checks if Langford can breathe after binding him, showing some concern for his condition.
Kidnaps and restrains Langford against his will, showing disregard for Langford's autonomy and safety.
Wishes himself luck and speaks in a casual tone to Marsha while holding Langford captive, showing detachment and lack of sincere concern for others.
Carefully restrains Langford with meticulous preparation and attention to detail, ensuring Langford can breathe.
Confidently speaks to Langford and Marsha, showing control over the situation.
Politely ends a phone call thanking Mr. Thomas for cooperation.
Engages in a secretive phone conversation with unknown parties.
Arranges a call with Bert Thomas, assures cooperation and promises to provide detailed information at the studio, demonstrating planning and confidence.
Does not reveal material details over the phone immediately, preferring an in-person meeting, which may indicate strategic thinking.
Walks purposefully down the street towards the theater.
Approaches cameraman and stage manager politely, trying to get their attention.
Claims 'I'm the King' to several staff members, possibly ignoring social cues.
Arrives at backstage door uninvited and walks into restricted area confidently.
Boldly claims 'I'm the King' to cameraman and stage manager to gain access.
Looks for a familiar face and tries to engage people backstage proactively.
After being frisked and held by plainclothesmen, he cooperates and talks with Patten; refers to Orson Bean in the autograph book, showing familiarity.
Maintains composure and tries to negotiate and communicate with kidnappers; gestures to autograph book to provide information.
Fails to provide clear information about Jerry Langford's whereabouts despite being questioned, potentially undermining his position.
Provides Bert Thomas with a neatly typewritten introduction to his act and requests it be followed exactly.
Requests make-up and insists on having color in his cheeks to improve appearance.
Neatly prepares and presents a carefully typewritten introduction to his act, ensuring the show will follow his directions exactly.
Requests make-up promptly and effectively to improve his appearance for the show.
Threatens that Jerry Langford is dead if he is not on the show.
Threatens violence to secure a spot on the show under duress, shows determination but through intimidation and desperation.
Gives lines to assistants preparing cue cards and rehearses with Tony Randall present, shows some organization and preparation.
Sweating and working under pressure, apparently beaten up before the show, indicating poor control over his situation.
Delivers a self-deprecating monologue that includes humor about his background and late mother, engaging the audience sincerely and warmly.
Waits nervously in the spotlight before appearing, showing vulnerability and a desire to connect with the audience.
Delivers a darkly humorous and self-deprecating monologue with timing that generates laughter from the crowd.
Uses exaggerated and absurd stories about family mishaps to evoke emotional response, demonstrating creativity and control over his material.
Focuses on self-pity and victimhood themes which risk alienating the audience, showing limited awareness of audience sensitivity.
Appears confident and composed on stage while weaving complex, layered humor despite disturbing content, indicating performance skill.
Implies a lack of traditional social or athletic skills from childhood but turns it into humorous content.
Uses humor and self-deprecation in his monologue, engaging the audience with sincerity and charm.
Hijacks Jerry Langford to break into show business, showing disregard for others' safety and feelings.
Soaks up the applause after his performance and is saluted by Tony Randall with a wave of his hand.
Says nothing in response to Mae's question and is hustled away by plainclothesmen, showing no engagement with autograph seekers.
Delivers a confident closing line with humor and receives applause, soaking up the audience's positive reaction.
Maintains silence and does not respond when questioned by the inspector despite evident pressure and physical coercion.
Proposes to watch the show together to ensure Jerry Langford's safety, attempts to cooperate to save him.
Insists on being released immediately and is evasive about Jerry's whereabouts, showing little trust or openness to the authorities.
Uses mollifying tones to calm Inspector Patten, preventing further conflict.
Argues about ransom demands with little regard for others' feelings, showing a manipulative edge.
Negotiates calmly to get ten dollars and exit despite inspector's hostility, uses mollifying tones to de-escalate situation.
Adds a demand for 'no Jerry Langford' despite agreement, showing sly manipulation.
Maintains composure and control after release, confidently walks into bar-restaurant flanked by guards.
Vaults onto the bar and changes the television channel, ignoring the moussy man who was watching first, showing impatience and disregard for others' feelings.
Watches his own monologue on TV with fascination, enjoying the positive response from the audience.
Stands with others watching rather than isolating himself, showing a willingness to share the moment.
Receives mixed reactions but remains composed, no signs of lashing out or hostility.
Delivers a monologue that successfully makes the audience laugh and receive applause, showing grasp of comedic timing and appeal.
Watches his act's reception with fascination and is accompanied by a grim Rita and a moody bystander, hinting at possible lack of full confidence or awareness of his performance impact.
Takes praise with a shy smile and looks for Rita's reaction, showing modesty and some sensitivity.
Tries to keep the mood light by urging Rita not to spoil the party and offers to pay for drinks.
Ignores escalating argument at the bar rather than intervening or calming the situation.
Takes praise from the crowd with a shy smile and offers to buy drinks to maintain the party atmosphere.
Attempts to engage others by ordering drinks but fails to secure any positive response.
Glances at Rita seeking approval, but she reacts sadly, indicating a lack of awareness or social perceptiveness.
Offers drinks to the stewed couple and tries to engage Rita in conversation despite the gloomy atmosphere.
Replies to Rita’s serious question about the kidnapping with a nod and a shrug, showing reserved acknowledgment.
Speaks in a quiet, tender voice to Rita, expressing care and wishing her well, asking her to think of him when bored.
Offers drinks to others and attempts to engage politely despite the situation.
Shrugs off serious concerns with an indifferent nod, showing emotional detachment.
Responds calmly and tenderly to Rita, showing composed interpersonal skills.
Delays compliance when plainclothesmen tell him to come along, showing slight resistance.
Smiles vaguely when told he will spend eight years in prison, showing a detached or indifferent response.
Appears in the Jerry Langford Show studio as a guest 'out on bail,' maintaining a public presence despite consequences.
Tapes Jerry Langford to the back of a brass bedstead on stage while they talk and laugh, culminating in a state of ecstasy and bowing to the audience.
Responds vaguely with 'We'll see' when told he faces eight years in prison, smiling calmly.
Successfully appears as a special guest on the Jerry Langford Show while out on bail, receiving enthusiastic applause from the audience.
Taping Jerry Langford to the back of a brass bedstead on stage and interacting with him in a playful manner, ending with a bow and smile showing satisfaction.
